Cryogenic sub-systems testing: The Cold Optics Chamber (COC)
The requirement for test and calibration facilities may be considered
a key component in the design and development of space
instrumentation.  Frequently, calibration facilities are purpose-built
for a single instrument, adding significantly to the overall programme
costs and schedule requirements. This is particularly true for
calibration under thermal balance, where the instrument's geometry and
mission-specific thermal requirements strongly dictate the cold wall
design and supporting cooling systems.
While large assemblies, or whole instruments, will generally
require complex and costly test and calibration facilities this is
frequently not the case for instrumentation comprising small
sub-assemblies, such as the cooled focal plane array of a telescope,
where the requirement to simulate thermal loading under operational
conditions may be met with more modest equipment. For such
sub-systems, therefore, the availability of versatile and
easily-configured test environments should convey many benefits, not
least of all reduced costs and a shorter processing time. It was these
considerations that lead to the design and construction of the Cold
Optics Chamber (COC) which is located in the department's <a
href="clean_assembly_area.html">Clean Assembly Area, along with
the Space View Chamber and the
<a href="thermal_cycling_chamber.html">Thermal Cycling
Chamber.
The COC comprises a cylindrical, 1 metre diameter stainless steel vacuum
vessel orientated vertically (centreline along the g-vector) and divided
into two unequal parts. The lower, smaller end-cap section is fixed to the
chamber support frame while the upper cylindrical section may be raised or
lowered using a mechanical hoist. The hoist has been designed to permit
rotation about its centreline so that the top chamber section may be swung
away from the centreline of the lower section. This arrangement provides
excellent access to the interior of the chamber while ensuring efficient
use of the available working volume.

The Cold Optics Chamber is also used to cool a White
cell (Fig
column2: 4) which is itself being used to study

column1: absorption by gases as a function of pressure, temperature and
wavelength. The White cell contains an arrangement of three mirrors
which, by multiple reflections, simulate absorption paths comparable
to those encountered in real atmospheres. As part of the experimental
configuration, a monochromatic beam of infrared radiation from a
medium resolution spectrometer is passed into the cell through
sapphire windows. The windows are fitted to both the vacuum chamber
and the cooled White cell, while the spectrometer is supported on the
optical bench adjacent to the vacuum chamber. After multiple
reflections the emerging beam is analysed and the degree of absoption
determined for the prevailing conditions.
